text: When I notice a body sensation, I pause and recognize it as normal instead of immediately assuming it's a sign of illness.
During moments of worry about my health, I notice the anxiety and choose to breathe and stay calm instead.
When I feel the urge to search online for symptoms, I recognize it as anxiety and choose to redirect my attention instead.
I let normal body sensations convince me that I have a serious illness or medical problem.
When I notice myself checking my body repeatedly, I recognize the pattern and choose to stop and redirect instead.
I see when my mind is catastrophizing a small symptom, and I choose a more realistic interpretation instead.
When I feel worry about my health rising, I notice it as anxiety and choose to observe it without reacting.
I let health anxiety drive me to excessive checking, searching, or worrying even when doctors say I'm healthy.
When I notice the pull to interpret every sensation as dangerous, I recognize it and choose to trust my body instead.
I recognize when my mind is confusing anxiety with real medical symptoms, and I choose to separate them.
When I feel the urge to seek reassurance about my health, I notice it and choose to sit with the uncertainty instead.
I let fear of serious illness control my thoughts and prevent me from living normally.
When I notice myself worrying about health even after reassurance, I recognize the pattern and choose to let it go.
I see when my mind is treating normal discomfort as a medical emergency, and I choose a calmer perspective instead.
When I feel the pull to research symptoms or medical information, I notice it and choose to redirect my focus instead.
I let health anxiety create excessive worry and checking behaviors that interfere with my daily life.
When I notice the cycle of worry starting—sensation, fear, checking—I interrupt it early by staying calm.
I recognize when my body sensations are caused by anxiety rather than actual illness, and I respond accordingly.
When I feel the urge to check my body for abnormalities, I notice it and choose to trust my body instead.
I let health anxiety prevent me from trusting my body or accepting reassurance from medical professionals.
